ABESS algorithm: details

Jin Zhu, Yanhang Zhang

1/20/2022

Source: vignettes/v10-algorithm.Rmd
v10-algorithm.Rmd

Introduction

The ABESS algorithm employing â€œsplicingâ€ technique can exactly solve general best subset problem in a polynomial time. The aim of this page to provide a complete and coherent documentation for ABESS algorithm such that users can easily understand the ABESS algorithm and its variants, thereby facilitating the usage of abess software. We provide the details of splicing approach to linear model as follows, and its variants can be applied in similar ways.

Linear model

Sacrifices

Consider the â„“0\ell_{0} constraint minimization problem, minğ›ƒâ„’n(ğ›ƒ), s.t âˆ¥ğ›ƒâˆ¥0â‰¤s, \min _{\boldsymbol{\beta}} \mathcal{L}_{n}(\boldsymbol{\beta}), \quad \text { s.t }\|\boldsymbol{\beta}\|_{0} \leq \mathrm{s}, where ${n}()=|y-X |{2}^{2}. $ Without loss of generality, we consider âˆ¥ğ›ƒâˆ¥0=s\|\boldsymbol{\beta}\|_{0}=\mathrm{s}. Given any initial set ğ’œâŠ‚ğ’®={1,2,â€¦,p}\mathcal{A} \subset \mathcal{S}=\{1,2, \ldots, p\} with cardinality |ğ’œ|=s|\mathcal{A}|=s, denote â„=ğ’œc\mathcal{I}=\mathcal{A}^{\mathrm{c}} and compute ğ›ƒÌ‚=argminğ›ƒâ„=0â„’n(ğ›ƒ). \hat{\boldsymbol{\beta}}=\arg \min _{\boldsymbol{\beta}_{\mathcal{I}}=0} \mathcal{L}_{n}(\boldsymbol{\beta}). We call ğ’œ\mathcal{A} and â„\mathcal{I} as the active set and the inactive set, respectively.

Given the active set ğ’œ\mathcal{A} and ğ›ƒÌ‚\hat{\boldsymbol{\beta}}, we can define the following two types of sacrifices:

  1. Backward sacrifice: For any jâˆˆğ’œj \in \mathcal{A}, the magnitude of discarding variable jj is, Î¾j=â„’n(ğ›ƒÌ‚ğ’œâˆ–{j})âˆ’â„’n(ğ›ƒÌ‚ğ’œ)=XjâŠ¤Xj2n(ğ›ƒÌ‚j)2, \xi_{j}=\mathcal{L}_{n}\left(\hat{\boldsymbol{\beta}}^{\mathcal{A} \backslash\{j\}}\right)-\mathcal{L}_{n}\left(\hat{\boldsymbol{\beta}}^{\mathcal{A}}\right)=\frac{X_{j}^{\top} X_{j}}{2 n}\left(\hat{\boldsymbol\beta}_{j}\right)^{2},
  2. Forward sacrifice: For any jâˆˆâ„j \in \mathcal{I}, the magnitude of adding variable jj is, Î¶j=â„’n(ğ›ƒğ’œÌ‚)âˆ’â„’n(ğ›ƒÌ‚ğ’œ+tÌ‚{j})=XjâŠ¤Xj2n(ğÌ‚jXjâŠ¤Xj/n)2. \zeta_{j}=\mathcal{L}_{n}\left(\hat{\boldsymbol{\beta}^{\mathcal{A}}}\right)-\mathcal{L}_{n}\left(\hat{\boldsymbol{\beta}}^{\mathcal{A}}+\hat{t}^{\{j\}}\right)=\frac{X_{j}^{\top} X_{j}}{2 n}\left(\frac{\hat{\boldsymbol d}_{j}}{X_{j}^{\top} X_{j} / n}\right)^{2}. where tÌ‚=argmintâ„’n(ğ›ƒÌ‚ğ’œ+t{j}),ğÌ‚j=XjâŠ¤(yâˆ’Xğ›ƒÌ‚)/n\hat{t}=\arg \min _{t} \mathcal{L}_{n}\left(\hat{\boldsymbol{\beta}}^{\mathcal{A}}+t^{\{j\}}\right), \hat{\boldsymbol d}_{j}=X_{j}^{\top}(y-X \hat{\boldsymbol{\beta}}) / n Intuitively, for jâˆˆğ’œj \in \mathcal{A} (or jâˆˆâ„j \in \mathcal{I} ), a large Î¾j\xi_{j} (or Î¶j\zeta_{j}) implies the jj th variable is potentially important.

Algorithm

Best-Subset Selection with a Given Support Size

Unfortunately, it is noteworthy that these two sacrifices are incomparable because they have different sizes of support set. However, if we exchange some â€œirrelevantâ€ variables in ğ’œ\mathcal{A} and some â€œimportantâ€ variables in â„\mathcal{I}, it may result in a higher-quality solution. This intuition motivates our splicing method. Specifically, given any splicing size kâ‰¤sk \leq s, define

ğ’œk={jâˆˆğ’œ:âˆ‘iâˆˆğ’œI(Î¾jâ‰¥Î¾i)â‰¤k} \mathcal{A}_{k}=\left\{j \in \mathcal{A}: \sum_{i \in \mathcal{A}} \mathrm{I}\left(\xi_{j} \geq \xi_{i}\right) \leq k\right\} to represent kk least relevant variables in ğ’œ\mathcal{A} and â„k={jâˆˆâ„:âˆ‘iâˆˆâ„âˆ£(Î¶jâ‰¤Î¶i)â‰¤k} \mathcal{I}_{k}=\left\{j \in \mathcal{I}: \sum_{i \in \mathcal{I}} \mid\left(\zeta_{j} \leq \zeta_{i}\right) \leq k\right\} to represent kk most relevant variables in â„.\mathcal{I} . Then, we splice ğ’œ\mathcal{A} and â„\mathcal{I} by exchanging ğ’œk\mathcal{A}_{k} and â„k\mathcal{I}_{k} and obtain a new active set ğ’œÌƒ=(ğ’œâˆ–ğ’œk)âˆªâ„k. \tilde{\mathcal{A}}=\left(\mathcal{A} \backslash \mathcal{A}_{k}\right) \cup \mathcal{I}_{k}. Let â„Ìƒ=ğ’œÌƒc,ğ›ƒÌƒ=argminğ›ƒâ„Â¯=0â„’n(ğ›ƒ)\tilde{\mathcal{I}}=\tilde{\mathcal{A}}^{c}, \tilde{\boldsymbol{\beta}}=\arg \min _{\boldsymbol{\beta}_{\overline{\mathcal{I}}}=0} \mathcal{L}_{n}(\boldsymbol{\beta}), and Ï„s>0\tau_{s}>0 be a threshold. If Ï„s<\tau_{s}<â„’n(ğ›ƒÌ‚)âˆ’â„’n(ğ›ƒÌƒ)\mathcal{L}_{n}(\hat{\boldsymbol\beta})-\mathcal{L}_{n}(\tilde{\boldsymbol\beta}), then AÌƒ\tilde{A} is preferable to ğ’œ.\mathcal{A} . The active set can be updated iteratively until the loss function cannot be improved by splicing. Once the algorithm recovers the true active set, we may splice some irrelevant variables, and then the loss function may decrease slightly. The threshold Ï„s\tau_{s} can reduce this unnecessary calculation. Typically, Ï„s\tau_{s} is relatively small, e.g.Â Ï„s=0.01slog(p)log(logn)/n.\tau_{s}=0.01 s \log (p) \log (\log n) / n.

Algorithm 1: BESS.Fix(s): Best-Subset Selection with a given support size s.
  1. Input: X,yX, y, positive integers kmax,mmaxk_{\max}, m_{\max}, and a threshold Ï„s\tau_{s}.
  2. Initialize ğ’œ0={j:âˆ‘i=1pI(|XjâŠ¤yXjâŠ¤Xj|â‰¤|XiâŠ¤yXiâŠ¤Xi|â‰¤s},â„0=(ğ’œ0)c\mathcal{A}^{0}=\left\{j: \sum_{i=1}^{p} \mathrm{I}\left(\left|\frac{X_{j}^{\top} y}{\sqrt{X_{j}^{\top} X_{j}}}\right| \leq \left| \frac{X_{i}^{\top} y}{\sqrt{X_{i}^{\top} X_{i}}}\right| \leq \mathrm{s}\right\}, \mathcal{I}^{0}=\left(\mathcal{A}^{0}\right)^{c}\right., and (ğ›ƒ0,d0):\left(\boldsymbol\beta^{0}, d^{0}\right):

ğ›ƒâ„00=0,dğ’œ00=0,ğ›ƒğ’œ00=(ğ—ğ’œ0âŠ¤ğ—ğ’œ0)âˆ’1ğ—ğ’œ0âŠ¤ğ²,dâ„00=Xâ„0âŠ¤(ğ²âˆ’ğ—ğ›ƒ0).\begin{align*} &\boldsymbol{\beta}_{\mathcal{I}^{0}}^{0}=0,\\ &d_{\mathcal{A}^{0}}^{0}=0,\\ &\boldsymbol{\beta}_{\mathcal{A}^{0}}^{0}=\left(\boldsymbol{X}_{\mathcal{A}^{0}}^{\top} \boldsymbol{X}_{\mathcal{A}^{0}}\right)^{-1} \boldsymbol{X}_{\mathcal{A}^{0}}^{\top} \boldsymbol{y},\\ &d_{\mathcal{I}^{0}}^{0}=X_{\mathcal{I}^{0}}^{\top}\left(\boldsymbol{y}-\boldsymbol{X} \boldsymbol{\beta}^{0}\right). \end{align*}

  1. For m=0,1,â€¦,mmaxm=0,1, \ldots, m_{\max}, do

    (ğ›ƒm+1,ğm+1,ğ’œm+1,â„m+1)=Splicing(ğ›ƒm,ğm,ğ’œm,â„m,kmax,Ï„s).\left(\boldsymbol{\beta}^{m+1}, \boldsymbol{d}^{m+1}, \mathcal{A}^{m+1}, \mathcal{I}^{m+1}\right)= \text{Splicing} \left(\boldsymbol{\beta}^{m}, \boldsymbol{d}^{m}, \mathcal{A}^{m}, \mathcal{I}^{m}, k_{\max }, \tau_{s}\right).

    If (ğ’œm+1,â„m+1)=(ğ’œm,â„m)\left(\mathcal{A}^{m+1}, \mathcal{I}^{m+1}\right)=\left(\mathcal{A}^{m}, \mathcal{I}^{m}\right), then stop

    End For

  2. Output (ğ›ƒÌ‚,ğÌ‚,ğ’œÌ‚,â„Ì‚)=(ğ›ƒm+1,ğm+1ğ’œm+1,â„m+1).(\hat{\boldsymbol{\beta}}, \hat{\boldsymbol{d}}, \hat{\mathcal{A}}, \hat{\mathcal{I}})=\left(\boldsymbol{\beta}^{m+1}, \boldsymbol{d}^{m+1} \mathcal{A}^{m+1}, \mathcal{I}^{m+1}\right).

Algorithm 2: Splicing (ğ›ƒ,d,ğ’œ,â„,kmax,Ï„s)\left(\boldsymbol\beta, d, \mathcal{A}, \mathcal{I}, k_{\max }, \tau_{s}\right)

  1. Input: ğ›ƒ,ğ,ğ’œ,â„,kmax\boldsymbol{\beta}, \boldsymbol{d}, \mathcal{A}, \mathcal{I}, k_{\max }, and Ï„s.\tau_{\mathrm{s}} .

  2. Initialize L0=L=12nâˆ¥yâˆ’XÎ²âˆ¥22L_{0}=L=\frac{1}{2 n}\|y-X \beta\|_{2}^{2}, and set Î¾j=XjâŠ¤Xj2n(Î²j)2,Î¶j=XjâŠ¤Xj2n(djXjâŠ¤Xj/n)2,j=1,â€¦,p.\xi_{j}=\frac{X_{j}^{\top} X_{j}}{2 n}\left(\beta_{j}\right)^{2}, \zeta_{j}=\frac{X_{j}^{\top} X_{j}}{2 n}\left(\frac{d_{j}}{X_{j}^{\top} X_{j} / n}\right)^{2}, j=1, \ldots, p.

  3. For k=1,2,â€¦,kmaxk=1,2, \ldots, k_{\max }, do

    ğ’œk={jâˆˆğ’œ:âˆ‘iâˆˆğ’œI(Î¾jâ‰¥Î¾i)â‰¤k}\mathcal{A}_{k}=\left\{j \in \mathcal{A}: \sum_{i \in \mathcal{A}} \mathrm{I}\left(\xi_{j} \geq \xi_{i}\right) \leq k\right\}

    â„k={jâˆˆâ„:âˆ‘iâˆˆâ„I(Î¶jâ‰¤Î¶i)â‰¤k}\mathcal{I}_{k}=\left\{j \in \mathcal{I}: \sum_{i \in \mathcal{I}} \mathrm{I}\left(\zeta_{j} \leq \zeta_{i}\right) \leq k\right\}

    Let ğ’œÌƒk=(ğ’œâˆ–ğ’œk)âˆªâ„k,â„Ìƒk=(â„âˆ–â„k)âˆªğ’œk\tilde{\mathcal{A}}_{k}=\left(\mathcal{A} \backslash \mathcal{A}_{k}\right) \cup \mathcal{I}_{k}, \tilde{\mathcal{I}}_{k}=\left(\mathcal{I} \backslash \mathcal{I}_{k}\right) \cup \mathcal{A}_{k} and solve

    ğ›ƒÌƒğ’œk=(ğ—ğ’œkâŠ¤ğ—ğ’œk)âˆ’1ğ—ğ’œkâŠ¤y,ğ›ƒÌƒâ„k=0\tilde{\boldsymbol{\beta}}_{{\mathcal{A}}_{k}}=\left(\boldsymbol{X}_{\mathcal{A}_{k}}^{\top} \boldsymbol{X}_{{\mathcal{A}}_{k}}\right)^{-1} \boldsymbol{X}_{{\mathcal{A}_{k}}}^{\top} y, \quad \tilde{\boldsymbol{\beta}}_{{\mathcal{I}}_{k}}=0

    ğÌƒâ„k=Xâ„kâŠ¤(yâˆ’XÎ²Ìƒ)/n,ğÌƒğ’œk=0.\tilde{\boldsymbol d}_{\mathcal{I}^k}=X_{\mathcal{I}^k}^{\top}(y-X \tilde{\beta}) / n,\quad \tilde{\boldsymbol d}_{\mathcal{A}^k} = 0.

    Compute â„’n(ğ›ƒÌƒ)=12nâˆ¥yâˆ’Xğ›ƒÌƒâˆ¥22.\mathcal{L}_{n}(\tilde{\boldsymbol\beta})=\frac{1}{2 n}\|y-X \tilde{\boldsymbol\beta}\|_{2}^{2}.

    If L>â„’n(ğ›ƒÌƒ)L>\mathcal{L}_{n}(\tilde{\boldsymbol\beta}), then

    (ğ›ƒÌ‚,ğÌ‚,ğ’œÌ‚,â„Ì‚)=(ğ›ƒÌƒ,ğÌƒ,ğ’œÌƒk,â„Ìƒk)(\hat{\boldsymbol{\beta}}, \hat{\boldsymbol{d}}, \hat{\mathcal{A}}, \hat{\mathcal{I}})=\left(\tilde{\boldsymbol{\beta}}, \tilde{\boldsymbol{d}}, \tilde{\mathcal{A}}_{k}, \tilde{\mathcal{I}}_{k}\right)

    L=â„’n(ğ›ƒÌƒ).L=\mathcal{L}_{n}(\tilde{\boldsymbol\beta}).

    End for

  4. If L0âˆ’L<Ï„sL_{0}-L<\tau_{s}, then (ğ›ƒÌ‚,dÌ‚,AÌ‚,IÌ‚)=(ğ›ƒ,d,ğ’œ,â„).(\hat{\boldsymbol\beta}, \hat{d}, \hat{A}, \hat{I})=(\boldsymbol\beta, d, \mathcal{A}, \mathcal{I}).

  5. Output (ğ›ƒÌ‚,ğÌ‚,ğ’œÌ‚,â„Ì‚)(\hat{\boldsymbol{\beta}}, \hat{\boldsymbol{d}}, \hat{\mathcal{A}}, \hat{\mathcal{I}}).

Determining the Best Support Size with SIC

In practice, the support size is usually unknown. We use a data-driven procedure to determine s. For any active set ğ’œ\mathcal{A}, define an SIC\mathrm{SIC} as follows: SIC(ğ’œ)=nlogâ„’ğ’œ+|ğ’œ|log(p)loglogn, \operatorname{SIC}(\mathcal{A})=n \log \mathcal{L}_{\mathcal{A}}+|\mathcal{A}| \log (p) \log \log n, where â„’ğ’œ=minÎ²â„=0â„’n(Î²),â„=(ğ’œ)c\mathcal{L}_{\mathcal{A}}=\min _{\beta_{\mathcal{I}}=0} \mathcal{L}_{n}(\beta), \mathcal{I}=(\mathcal{A})^{c}. To identify the true model, the model complexity penalty is logp\log p and the slow diverging rate loglogn\log \log n is set to prevent underfitting. Theorem 4 states that the following ABESS algorithm selects the true support size via SIC.

Let smaxs_{\max } be the maximum support size. We suggest smax=o(nlogp)s_{\max }=o\left(\frac{n}{\log p}\right) as the maximum possible recovery size. Typically, we set smax=[nlog(p)loglogn]s_{\max }=\left[\frac{n}{\log (p) \log \log n}\right] where [x][x] denotes the integer part of xx.

Algorithm 3: ABESS.

  1. Input: X,yX, y, and the maximum support size smax.s_{\max } .

  2. For s=1,2,â€¦,smaxs=1,2, \ldots, s_{\max }, do

    (ğ›ƒÌ‚s,ğÌ‚s,ğ’œÌ‚s,â„Ì‚s)=BESS.Fixed(s).\left(\hat{\boldsymbol{\beta}}_{s}, \hat{\boldsymbol{d}}_{s}, \hat{\mathcal{A}}_{s}, \hat{\mathcal{I}}_{s}\right)= \text{BESS.Fixed}(s).

    End for

  3. Compute the minimum of SIC:

    smin=argminsSIC(ğ’œÌ‚s).s_{\min }=\arg \min _{s} \operatorname{SIC}\left(\hat{\mathcal{A}}_{s}\right).

  4. Output (ğ›ƒÌ‚smin,ğÌ‚smin,AÌ‚smin,â„Ì‚smin).\left(\hat{\boldsymbol{\beta}}_{s_{\operatorname{min}}}, \hat{\boldsymbol{d}}_{s_{\min }}, \hat{A}_{s_{\min }}, \hat{\mathcal{I}}_{s_{\min }}\right) .

The corresponding notations in abess() function

Notations in algorithm Parameters in ğšŠğš‹ğšğšœğšœ\mathtt{abess} Definitions
mmaxm_{\max} max.splicing.iter The maximum number of splicing algorithm
kmaxk_{\max} c.max The maximum splicing size
1,â€¦,smax1,\ldots,s_{\max} support.size A sequence representing the support sizes
SIC\operatorname{SIC} tune.type The type of criterion for choosing the support size
{G1,â€¦,GJ}\{G_1, \ldots, G_J\} group.index A vector indicator the group that each variable belongs to
Î»\lambda lambda A value for regularized best subset selection
Golden-section searching gs.range Upper and lower bounds of the search range
